BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE:
In 2017, the Department of Commerce (DOC) was asked to conduct an investigation into the impact on our national security from imports of steel mill products and from imports of wrought and unwrought aluminum. These investigations were carried out under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962, as amended. On January 11, 2018, the DOC formally submitted to President Trump the results of the investigation. On March 8, 2018 President Trump announced Presidential Proclamations 9704 and 9705 ordering Section 232 tariffs on imports of steel and aluminum. The Secretary of Commerce has the authority to grant exclusions from the duties, “if the steel or aluminum articles are determined not to be in a sufficient and reasonable available amount or of a satisfactory quality or based upon specific national security considerations.” Individuals or organizations using steel articles in business activities or supplying steel to users in the U.S. may submit exclusion requests with respect to the Proclamation. In addition, any individual or organization in the U.S. can file objections to exclusions. The DOC’s Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) has the lead on national security analysis. The Enforcement and Compliance (E&C) unit of the DOC’s International Trade Administration is responsible for providing technical analyses for product exclusions related to the proceedings and submitting a recommendation to BIS on whether the technical merits of the request and objections warrant approving or denying the exclusion request. Currently, E&C does not have sufficient staff resources with the expertise required to evaluate the exclusion requests and objections to requests. Information on the exclusion procedures can be found here: https://www.bis.doc.gov/index.php/232-steel

The Radiography Scientist (Scientist 4) will work as part of an experimental and analysis team that fields Hydrotests at the DARHT (Dual Axis Radiographic Hydrodynamic Test Facility) in Los Alamos, NM USA, and other high energy radiography facilities. The Radiography Scientist 4's primary responsibility is to use software tools and analysis techniques to analyze radiographic image data from hydrodynamic experiments. The Scientist 4 is expected to provide leadership in maintaining and building upon existing analysis tools and standards with the goal of improving analysis efficiency and increasing understanding of radiographic data. Typical radiographic diagnostics consist of world class, ultra-fast, radiographic detectors that convert high-energy, MHz rate, pulsed x-rays into images of imploding hydrotests. A second responsibility is to support the design and fielding of the radiographic / optical chain used in DARHT hydrotests, such as the design of graded collimators. He/she will be part of the Experiments and Diagnostics Group, J-4, in the Integrated Weapons Experiments Division, J. J-4 is responsible for all aspects of data collection, data analysis, experimental integration, and experimental timing of DARHT experiments. Typical DARHT experiments consists of explosions of mock-nuclear devices that are contained in 6-foot, submarine steel vessels. The work is varied and interesting; it includes design, analysis, development, and research. The environment at DARHT is collaborative (with two other groups), meticulously choreographed, and formal.

Demonstrated experience developing data analysis methods and capabilities. Advanced knowledge and application of fundamental data and image processing techniques. Demonstrated experience analyzing and interpreting data from complex experiments using multi-disciplinary software tools and accepted methods and metrics.



Demonstrated advanced experience in the field of flash radiography, with emphasis on high energy radiography of dynamic (i.e. fast moving) experiments.



Demonstrated advanced experience using computerized data acquisition systems. Demonstrated knowledge of data file formats, architectures, and data acquisition electronics (primarily COTS).



Demonstrated experience designing and fielding complex physics experiments to answer scientific questions. Basic knowledge of the physical processes of radiation interactions, detection and measurements.


Demonstrated ability to work with a diverse team of professionals including technicians, engineers, and scientists including effective communication skills for all levels. Further demonstrated ability to leverage ingenuity, creativity, and personal independence to support multiple concurrent team tasks.



Position requires an Advanced Degree in Physics, Electrical Engineering, Optical Engineering, Nuclear Engineering, or other related field and a minimum of 10 years of related experience. A PhD is strongly preferred.





Demonstrated advanced knowledge analyzing radiographic digital image data to obtain physical properties of the objects under test. Demonstrated development of innovative image analysis techniques and capabilities that define technical direction.



Experience working in an environment where Operational Formality was required.



Demonstrated experience developing complex computer code to analyze data. Demonstrated experience using existing software platforms and tools to analyze data. Demonstrated experience in accepted, formal code development methods and documentation. Experience developing data acquisition software.

Title: Product Design Engineer
Job_Description:
What You Will Do

The Hydrotest Diagnostics Operator (Engineered Systems Technician IV) will operate, deploy, and maintain some of the most sophisticated radiographic, optical, and electronic instruments at Los Alamos. He/she will be part of the Experiments and Diagnostics Group, J-4, in the Integrated Weapons Experiments Division, J. These diagnostics consist of ultra-fast imaging cameras that are used to convert radiographic (X-rays) measurements into images of imploding hydrotests, and laser / fiber optic-based systems that provide quantitative measurements of the implosion dynamics. J-4 is responsible for all aspects of data collection, data analysis, experimental integration, and experimental timing of DARHT experiments. (DARHT is the Dual Axis Radiographic Hydrodynamic Test facility.) The DARHT experiments are explosions of mock-nuclear devices that are contained in 6 foot, submarine steel vessels. The work is varied and interesting; it includes operation, deployment, repair, and troubleshooting. J-4 is also responsible for the operation of the central control system for DARHT, called the DARHT Detection Chamber or DDC. The environment at DARHT is collaborative (with two other groups), meticulously choreographed, and formal.

We are looking for people with a solid technical background in either mechanics, electronics, or both and we will teach you the rest. J-4 has an extensive training program based on On-The-Job training, mentoring, and formal (short, 1 week) courses. The accumulation of the competency in electronic control systems, radiography, lasers, optics, and dynamic experiments provides a natural path for promotion so that working in J-4 is a career opportunity. Much of the training is provided by mentoring under some of the most innovative and capable Ph.D. scientists and engineers at Los Alamos.

Specific roles and responsibilities include:







Understanding of basic electronics including the ability to read electrical schematics and identify electronic components both physically and as symbols on a schematic diagram.
